overview_of_class: This course focuses on the development of communication and design skills necessary for presentations at the graduate level. Course content will concentrate on improving methods of designing and delivering oral presentations to audiences using visual aids. Over the course of the class, students will have opportunities to improve their presentation design and delivery in English through the observation, creation, peer-evaluation, and practice of short academic presentations. In so doing, students will develop skills in visual design fundamentals; oral communication strategies; audience awareness and engagement; and English vocabulary frequently used in academic presentations. This course is designed to give students confidence and experience that is transferable to a variety of academic contexts, including class presentations, research reports, job interviews, conference presentations, and teaching and/or leading class discussion sections. Active participation and evidence of progress towards proficiency must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in this course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Instructor consent required

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:

1. Identify personal strengths and weaknesses in their communicative competence in American English (i.e. linguistic competence, sociolinguistic competence, discourse competence, functional competence, and strategic competence) from the use of data from self-assessments and instructor feedback.
2. Demonstrate progress toward proficiency in using English for academic purposes, e.g.,
a. Improve verbal communication skills required for academic presentations in both casual settings (e.g., office-hours consultations) and formal settings (e.g., job talks)
b. Improve written communication skills required for academic presentations, e.g., organization and composition of posters, slides, and handouts.
c. Utilize various skills required for clear and effective communication across these modalities, e.g., use of conjunctions for smooth flow of verbal and/or written ideas; appropriate use of focus and emphasis in exposition; strategies for responding to questions
d. Identify and employ different strategies needed for successful communication in different situations, e.g., understanding differences between formal and casual register and terms of address; use of acronyms and jargon for expert audiences vs. plain English for lay audiences
3. Express themselves in American English more comfortably and confidently.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Small group activities, discussion, lecture, online exercises, and presentations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on in-class participation, homework assignments, and presentations.

subject: LING

overview_of_class: This course is focused on fluency and comprehensibility in conversation in both informal and academic settings. It is designed to help students develop and refine their English conversation, discussion, and discourse skills. While some attention will be given to American English intonation, word stress, and pronunciation, the primary purpose of this class is to explore functions of American English important for fluency in conversational speech. This will help improve your performance on tasks and activities involving spoken English, such as oral proficiency exams, presentations, teaching, and day-to-day social interactions. Active participation and evidence of progress towards proficiency must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in the course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:

1. Identify personal strengths and weaknesses in their communicative competence in American English (i.e., e.g., linguistic competence, sociolinguistic competence, discourse competence, functional competence, and strategic competence) from the use of data from self-assessments and instructor feedback.
2. Communicate effectively in a variety of settings and situations, including casual and formal conversations; academic talks; persuasive speeches; group discussions; and discussions about controversial issues.
3. Utilize various linguistic and functional skills required for clear and effective communication across these modalities, e.g., conversational turn-taking skills; appropriate use of focus and emphasis in discourse; strategies for responding to questions.
4. Identify and employ different strategies needed for successful communication in different situations, e.g., understanding differences between formal and casual register and terms of address; appropriate use of colloquialisms, euphemisms, and idioms depending on the audience.
5. Express themselves in American English more comfortably and confidently.
6. Show demonstrable progress toward proficiency in using English for conversational purposes.

The concepts introduced in these readings and assignments will form the basis for classroom work, so it is important that you complete them in advance of the class for which they are assigned. You will also be assessed on attendance and participation.
